description: This course will investigate historical and contemporary philosophical views on the role of the emotions in the arts. Do we have genuine emotional responses to works of art - to fiction? paintings? music? If so, what are the conditions under which we do and don't have such emotional responses? When are such responses appropriate? In particular, does an appropriate aesthetic attitude require emotional distance from the object of the artwork? Is it inappropriate to respond emotionally to morally depraved artworks? How do formal devices induce, constrain, and otherwise alter our emotional responses to art? Readings will be drawn from philosophers including Jean-Baptise Du Bos, David Hume, Edmund Burke, Moses Mendelssohn, Henry Home Lord Kames, Arthur Schopenhauer, Edward Bullough, R.G. Collingwood, Stanley Cavell, Tamar Szabo Gendler, Richard Moran, Kendall Walton, and others.

values.comments:
This course investigates historical and contemporary philosophical views on the role of the emotions in the arts. Do we have genuine emotional responses to works of art? To fiction? Paintings? Music? If so, what are the conditions under which we do and don\'t have such emotional responses? When are such responses appropriate? In particular, does an appropriate aesthetic attitude require emotional distance from the object of the artwork? Is it inappropriate to respond emotionally to morally depraved artworks? How do formal devices induce, constrain, and otherwise alter our emotional responses to art? Readings are drawn from philosophers including Jean-Baptise Du Bos, David Hume, Edmund Burke, Moses Mendelssohn, Henry Home Lord Kames, Arthur Schopenhauer, Edward Bullough, R.G. Collingwood, Stanley Cavell, Tamar Szabo Gendler, Richard Moran, Kendall Walton, and others.

Students found the content of the course to be “excellent” and described the readings as “fascinating.” One student wrote that “The quality of the readings is borne out in research: everything we read appears time and again in the main discourses of this material in almost all the sources I find independent of the course.” The amount learned from this course was high.

Professor Guyer was regarded by the students as “engaging.” He “stimulated discussion” and was extremely knowledgeable. Students were very pleased with the back and forth between Professor Guyer and his co-professor. One student wrote that Professors “Camp & Guyer did a wonderful job of not only bringing their respective viewpoints/fields to the table, but successfully reconciled them and played them off of each other, all the while allowing students a very active role in discussion.”

Regarding the work outside this course, one student complained that there was “too much reading per week… and [it was] hard to coordinate presentations in pairs.” The amount of work required by this course was high. This course was also rated fairly difficult. This course was recommended strongly to majors and less so to non-majors.
